Feature: Are there definite or specific articles?
Do indefinite nominals commonly have indefinite articles?
Are there prenominal articles?
Are there postnominal articles?
What is the order of numeral and noun in the NP?
What is the order of adnominal demonstrative and noun?
Example: taj del [that head] ’that head’

Feature: Can adnominal property words occur discontinuously?
Example:
bọjunmọ va:ča:v anamma
[deer kill.PST fat]
‘I/You/He/She (Masc.) has/have killed a deer, a fat one.’

Feature: Are nominal conjunction and comitative expressed by different elements?
Example:
əmən asatka-kkan bi-ča-n amin-ǯi
[one girl-DIM be-PST-3SG father-INS]
’A girl lived with the father.’
ətixən-ǯi atixan-ǯi bi-ča-tin
[old.man-INS old.woman-INS be-PST-3PL]
‘There lived an old man with an old woman.’

Feature: Is there an inclusive/exclusive distinction?
Example: bu: [1PL.EXCL],  bitt@ [1PL.INCL]

Feature: Is there a gender distinction in independent 3rd person pronouns?
Is there a dual or unit augmented form (in addition to plural or augmented) for all person categories in the pronoun system?
Are there three or more distance contrasts in demonstratives?
Detailed comment: There is a two-way distinction.
Example: əj ‘this’, taj ‘that’

Feature: Do demonstratives show an elevation distinction?
Do demonstratives show a visible-nonvisible distinction?
Are there demonstrative classifiers?
Is there nonphonological allomorphy of noun number markers?
Comment: Not clear, whether it is phonological or not
Detailed comment: Suffixes -l, -sal, -səl, -sel
Example:
dZo: [house] - dZo:-sal [house-PL]
adel [net] - adeli-l, adeli-sal [net-PL]
mojn [horse] - moji-l, moji-sal [horse-PL]

Feature: Are there several nouns (more than three) which are suppletive for number?
Is there productive overt morphological singular marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological dual marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological plural marking on nouns?
Detailed comment: Suffixes -l, -sal, -səl, -sel
Example:
dZo: [house] - dZo:-sal [house-PL]
adel [net] - adeli-l, adeli-sal [net-PL]
mojn [horse] - moji-l, moji-sal [horse-PL]

Feature: Is there an associative plural marker for nouns?
Comment: “Plural forms of some kinship terms have an associative meaning rather than additive one.”
Example:
am-til
[father-ASS]
’parents’

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an action/state noun from a verb?
Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an agent noun from a verb?
Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an object noun from a verb?
Comment: ‘an instrument or a result of an action’
Detailed comment: -wun ‘an instrument or a result of an action’
Example:
egdi-wun
[comb.hair-NMLZ]
’a comb’

Feature: Is there a noun class/gender system where sex is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where shape is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where animacy is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where plant status is a factor in class assignment?
Are there numeral classifiers?
Are there possessive classifiers?
Is the adnominal possessive construction different for alienable and inalienable nouns?
Detailed comment:
There are three types of possession: inalienable, alienable and absolute.
Inalienable possession is formed by personal or reflexive suffixes on the noun.
Alienable possession is formed by suffixes -N, -Ni on the noun.
Absolutive possession is formed by suffixes -Ni:, Ni: on the noun if the noun is in subject position or a substitution of the noun in genitive form or an inversed attribution.
Example:
inalienable: deli-nin [head-3SG] ‘his head’ (part of his body)
alienable: deli-Ni-nin [head-POSS-3SG] ‘his head’ (of the animal, slaughtered by him)
absolutive: taj del mojin-Ni [that head horse-POSS] ‘that head is the horse’s one’

Feature: What is the pragmatically unmarked order of adnominal possessor noun and possessed noun?
Example:
deli-Ni-nin [head-POSS-3SG] ‘his head’ (of the animal, slaughtered by him)
a:vum me:taxsa biča:n ZuksEnin xoxom biča:n sama:six
[hat be.PST bag be.PST shaman]

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like verbs in predicative position?
Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as verbs?
Are there morphological cases for non-pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Detailed comment: There is a nominative, an accusative and an indefinite accusative cases.

Feature: Are there morphological cases for pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Detailed comment: There is a nominative and an accusative case.

Feature: Are there morphological cases for oblique non-pronominal NPs (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Detailed comment: There are 6 olbique cases: dative, allative, locative, prosecutive, instrumental (terminology in approximate translation from Russian).

Feature: Are there morphological cases for oblique independent personal pronouns (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Detailed comment: There are 6 oblique cases marked by suffixes on personal pronouns.

Feature: Are there prepositions?
Are there postpositions?
Detailed comment: Postpositions take case and possessive suffixes
Example: dZo: ojo-du:-n ‘on the house’, ujkə daGa-la:-n ‘near the door’

Feature: Do verbs have prefixes/proclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Do verbs have suffixes/enclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Example: va:-ča:-v [kill-PST-1SG] ‘I killed.’

Feature: Is there productive infixation in verbs?
Is there overt morphological marking of present tense on verbs?
Comment: “General tense is also known as present, present-past, Praesens (Perfectum 1) and refers equally to presence or to past and occasionally to future.”

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to past tense?
Detailed comment: suffix -ča-
Example: va:-ča:-v [kill-PST-1SG] ‘I killed.’

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to future tense?
Detailed comment: -ǯa-

Feature: Is a morphological distinction between perfective and imperfective aspect available on verbs?
Detailed comment:
-s-
‑ǯa~‑ǯə an imperfective marker
Example:
čixa-s- ‘be cutting’, xoda-s- ‘be selling’
bi-ǯə- 
[live-IPFV]
‘to live (for a long time)’

Feature: Can the S argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Detailed comment: there is indexing of the person of the subject

Feature: Can the S argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Detailed comment: there is indexing of the person of the subject

Feature: Can the A argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the P argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on TAM distinctions?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on verb classes?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on person distinctions?
Can verb stems alter according to the person of a core participant?
Is there a benefactive applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Is there an instrumental applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Can the recipient in a ditransitive construction be marked like the monotransitive patient?
Can standard negation be marked by an affix, clitic or modification of the verb?
Is there directional or locative morphological marking on verbs?
Comment: "Like other Tungusic languages (cf. Stojnova 2016, to appear), the North Tungusic languages have an associated motion suffix –nA that expresses mainly andative meanings, but can have ventive readings as well. This adds a directional argument to the argument structure”

Feature: Is there verb suppletion for participant number?
Detailed comment: There is no suppletion whatsoever.

Feature: Is there verb suppletion for tense or aspect?
Detailed comment: There is no suppletion whatsoever.

Feature: Are there conjugation classes?
Are there verbal affixes or clitics that turn intransitive verbs into transitive ones?
Is there a phonologically bound reflexive marker on the verb?
Is there a phonologically bound reciprocal marker on the verb?
Detailed comment: Suffix -ma:t-/č-
Example: va:-ma:t-/č- ‘kill each other’, bu:-ma:t-/-č- ‘give each other'

Feature: Do verbs classify the shape, size or consistency of absolutive arguments by means of incorporated nouns, verbal affixes or suppletive verb stems?
Is there a copula for predicate nominals?
Are there serial verb constructions?
Can mood be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Detailed comment: auxiliary verb bi- ‘to be’ or o:- ‘to become’
Example:
va:-dZa bi-si-m [kill-FUT be-POT-1SG] ‘I should kill.’
va:-dZa bi-si-s [kill-FUT be-POT-2SG] ‘You should kill.’

Feature: Can aspect be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Can tense be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Detailed comment: Perfect is derived from a past participle of a notional verb and an auxiliary verb bi- ‘be’ in general tense. Pluperfect is derived from a past participle of a notional verb and an auxiliary verb bi- ‘be’ in past tense.”"
Example:
Ana:! Bəgdi-ji molkel-ča bi-si-m
[oh leg-POSS.REFL.SG break-PTCP.PST be-PRSPST-1SG]
‘Oh (it hurts)! I have broken my leg.’

Feature: Is verb compounding a regular process?
Are there verb-adjunct (aka light-verb) constructions?
Is incorporation of nouns into verbs a productive intransitivizing process?
Is there an existential verb?
Are different posture verbs used obligatorily depending on an inanimate locatum's shape or position (e.g. 'to lie' vs. 'to stand')?
Is there a notably small number, i.e. about 100 or less, of verb roots in the language?
What is the pragmatically unmarked order of S and V in intransitive clauses?
Example: omon bEjeNEnEjen ‘One person went in autumn.’

Feature: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-initial for transitive clauses?
Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-medial for transitive clauses?
Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-final for transitive clauses?
Is the order of constituents the same in main and subordinate clauses?
Do clausal objects usually occur in the same position as nominal objects?
Comment: There are not enough clausal examples available.

Feature: Is the order of core argument (i.e. S/A/P) constituents fixed?
Can standard negation be marked clause-finally?
Comment: marked on the verb, which appears to be clause-finally

Feature: Can standard negation be marked clause-initially?
Is there a difference between imperative (prohibitive) and declarative negation constructions?
Detailed comment: both with a negative verb ə- and a connegative of the notional verb, but the verb in declarative negation bears finiteness markers, the negative auxiliary is marked for imperative and person
Example:
ə-xəl bu:-jə
[NEG-IMP.2SG give-CONNEG]
‘do not give (it)!’
taj bəjə ə-ti ŋɵ:lə-jə bi-čə-n
[that man NEG-PTCP.PRS be.afraid-CONNEG be-PST-3SG]
‘that man was not afraid’
loxon-mi omŋo-čo bi-mi ə-čə ŋunu-jə
[sword-POSS.REFL.SG forget-PTCP.PST be-CVB1 NEG-PST return-CONNEG]
’(he) left his sword and did not return’

Feature: Is verbal predication marked by the same negator as all of the following types of predication: locational, existential and nominal?
Is there a morpho-syntactic distinction between predicates expressing controlled versus uncontrolled events or states?
Is there a morphological passive marked on the lexical verb?
Detailed comment: Suffix -v, -mu
Example:
va:-v- [kill-PASS] ‘be killed’, iče-v- [see-PASS] ‘be seen’
ujguli-du wa:-w-ča:-n
[huge.bear-DAT kill-PASS-PST-3SG]
‘(He) was killed by a huge bear.’

Feature: Is there a morphological antipassive marked on the lexical verb?
Is there a morphologically marked inverse on verbs?
Is there clause chaining?
Example:
loxon-mi omŋo-čo bi-mi ə-čə ŋunu-jə
[sword-POSS.REFL.SG forget-PTCP.PST be-CVB1 NEG-PST return-CONNEG]
’(he) left his sword and did not return’

Feature: Is there an overt verb marker dedicated to signalling coreference or noncoreference between the subject of one clause and an argument of an adjacent clause ("switch reference")?
Is there a morphologically marked distinction between simultaneous and sequential clauses?
Are causatives formed by affixes or clitics on verbs?
Detailed comment: -vka:n, -mka:n, -vka:t-/č-, -mka:t-/č-
Example:
iče-vka:n- [see-CAUS] ‘show, let sb see’
zepu-vka:t-/č- [eat-CAUS] ’ask to eat’

Feature: Is there a causative construction involving an element that is unmistakably grammaticalized from a verb for 'to say'?
Are verbs reduplicated?
Are nouns reduplicated?
Are elements apart from verbs or nouns reduplicated?
Comment: Ideophones seem to be formed by reduplication (not clear whether reduplicated elements constitute phonological words).
Example: bagda-bagda ‘very white’, xola-xola ‘very red’, tak-tax ‘to keep tight’

Feature: Is there productive morphological trial marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological paucal marking on nouns?
Is there a logophoric pronoun?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Detailed comment: There is no class/gender system.

Feature: Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Detailed comment: There is no class/gender system.

Feature: Can an article agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Can the verb carry a marker of animacy of argument, unrelated to any gender/noun class of the argument visible in the NP domain?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in number?
Comment: Adjectives receive number marking only used independently. They remain unmarked when used adnominally.
Detailed comment:
Compare the adjective baja- without number suffix in adnominal position and with plural suffix -sal used independently:
taj dZo: bEjenin bajan bEjel ‘the rich people of that house’ - no agreement
bajasal xutEvEtin gača: ‘bought a daughter from those rich (people)’
Example:
bajan bəje-l
[rich person-PL]
‘rich people’

Feature: Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in number?
Can an article agree with the noun in number?
Is there any productive diminutive marking on the noun (exclude marking by system of nominal classification only)?
Detailed comment: Suffixes -xa:n, -ka:n, -kka:n
Example:
dət ‘swamp’ - dətka:n ‘small swamp’
beja ‘river’ - bejaxka:n ‘small river, stream’

Feature: Is there any productive augmentative marking on the noun (exclude marking by system of nominal classification only)?
Detailed comment: Suffixes -xa:ja:, -ka:ja:, -ndZa, -ndZe
Example: bəje-xa:ja: [human-AUG], bəje-ndZe [human-AUG] ‘a huge human’

Feature: Is there a gender system where a noun's phonological properties are a factor in class assignment?
What is the order of adnominal property word and noun?
Possible Values: multistate 1: ANM - N; 2: N - ANM; 3: both; 0: they cannot be used attributively
Example:
bajan bəje-l
[rich person-PL]
‘rich people’

Feature: Is there a male/female distinction in 2nd person independent pronouns?
Is there a male/female distinction in 1st person independent pronouns?
Can an adnominal numeral agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Detailed comment: There is no class/gender system.

Feature: What is the order of the adnominal collective universal quantifier ('all') and the noun?
Example: čopal ‘all; whole’ (Lower Negidal), opkači(n) ‘all’ (Upper Negidal)

Feature: Do collective ('all') and distributive ('every') universal quantifiers differ in their forms or their syntactic positions?
Can predicative possession be expressed with a transitive 'habeo' verb?
Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a locative-coded possessor?
Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a dative-coded possessor?
Example:
taj bəjə-l-du hute-tin bi-ča-n 
that person-PL-DAT offspring-POSS.3PL be-PST-3SG 
‘Those people had a child’

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a possessor that is coded like an adnominal possessor?
Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessor and a possessum that is coded like a comitative argument?
Can polar interrogation be marked by intonation only?
Can polar interrogation be indicated by a special word order?
Is there a clause-initial polar interrogative particle?
Is there a clause-final polar interrogative particle?
Example:
čewka:ŋ-ŋa-s ǯəb-ǯə-m=ŋu
[little.bird-ACC.DEF-POSS.2SG eat-FUT-1SG=Q]
’May I eat your little bird?

Feature: Is there a polar interrogative particle that most commonly occurs neither clause-initially nor clause-finally?
Is there a comparative construction that includes a form that elsewhere means 'surpass, exceed'?
Is there a comparative construction that employs a marker of the standard which elsewhere has a locational meaning?
Detailed comment: With an ablative case
Example:
bi axinmi: məjGəndukkin ajadZi məjGəlko:n bisim [1SG brother.own mind better mind have.PTCP be] ‘I’m cleverer than my brother.’
вolin bʊga bəjə-l-dukki-n maŋga bəjə a:čin
[middle place man-PL-ABL-POSS.3SG strong man NEG.EXIST]
’There are no people stronger than people of the middle land.’

Feature: Can comparatives be expressed using two conjoined clauses?
Is there a comparative construction with a standard marker that elsewhere has neither a locational meaning nor a 'surpass/exceed' meaning?
Is there a bound comparative degree marker on the property word in a comparative construction?
Is there a non-bound comparative degree marker modifying the property word in a comparative construction?
Can polar interrogation be marked by a question particle and verbal morphology?
Can polar interrogation be indicated by overt verbal morphology only?
Can polar interrogation be marked by tone?
Is there a phonologically or morphosyntactically definable class of ideophones that includes ideophones depicting imagery beyond sound?
Comment: Ideophones are characterized by consonantal auslaut and pairwise usage. They function as adverbs.

Feature: Can polar interrogation be indicated by a V-not-V construction?
Can standard negation be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Detailed comment: auxiliary verb E- and a lexical verb marked by suffix -ja, -je or its phonetic variants
Example:
E-sim va:ja [NEG-PRS.1SG kill.PTCP] ‘I don’t kill’
E-čev va:ja [NEG-PST.1SG kill.PTCP] ‘I didn’t kill’
E-ta:m va:ja [NEG-FUT.1SG kill.PTCP] ‘I won’t kill’
E-xEl va:ja [NEG-PRS.1SG kill.PTCP] ‘don’t kill!’

Feature: Can standard negation be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Does the verb for 'give' have suppletive verb forms?
Detailed comment: There is no suppletion whatsoever.

Feature: Is there an inclusory construction?
Is there a phonologically free passive marker ('particle' or 'auxiliary')?
Is there a phonologically free antipassive marker ('particle' or 'auxiliary')?
Can the agent be expressed overtly in a passive clause?
Example:
ujguli-du wa:-w-ča:-n
[huge.bear-DAT kill-PASS-PST-3SG]
‘(He) was killed by a huge bear.’

Feature: Is there a phonologically independent reflexive pronoun?
Example:
ma:nmi: ‘oneself (SG)’
ma:nmoj ‘oneself (PL)’

Feature: Is there a phonologically independent non-bipartite reciprocal pronoun?
Are there multiple past or multiple future tenses, distinguishing distance from Time of Reference?
Example:
past: 
va:-ča:-v
[kill-PST-1SG]
‘I killed.’
pluperfect:
va-ča bi-si-m
[kill-PST be-PST-1SG]
‘I had killed.’
near future:
amban minə-wə ǯəpu-l-lə-n
[devil 1SG-ACC.DEF eat-PROSP-PRSPST-3SG ‘the devil is about to eat me up’
distant future:
sunə-wə ǯəpu-l-ǯa:-n 2PL-ACC.DEF eat-INCH-FUT-3SG
‘he will eat you (pl.)’

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to mood?
Detailed comment: volitionality: -mu-si, -tče
Example:
iče-mu-si-
[see-VOL-VOL]
‘be willing to see’
iče-itče-
[see-VOL]
‘be striving to see’

Feature: Are there special adnominal possessive pronouns that are not formed by an otherwise regular process?
Example: min [1SG], sin [2SG], noNan [3SG], mun [1PL.EXCL], bittE [1PL.INCL], sun [2PL], noNatil [3PL]

Feature: Can augmentative meaning be expressed productively by a shift of gender/noun class?
Can diminutive meaning be expressed productively by a shift of gender/noun class?
Is singular number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is dual number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is plural number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is trial number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is paucal number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is there a large class of nouns whose gender/noun class is not phonologically or semantically predictable?
Is there grammatical marking of direct evidence (perceived with the senses)?
Is there grammatical marking of indirect evidence (hearsay, inference, etc.)?
Is there an interrogative verb for content interrogatives (who?, what?, etc.)?
Detailed comment: interrogative pronouns ni: ~ Ni: ‘who’ and e:xun ‘what/who’
Example:
ni: əmə-ča:
[who come-PST]
‘who has come?’

Feature: Is there a count/mass distinction in interrogative quantifiers?
Do (nominal) content interrogatives normally or frequently occur in situ?
Can the relative clause follow the noun?
Comment: There are not enough clausal examples available.

Feature: Can the relative clause precede the noun?
Comment: There are not enough clausal examples available.

Feature: Are there internally-headed relative clauses?
Comment: There are not enough clausal examples available.

Feature: Are there correlative relative clauses?
Comment: There are not enough clausal examples available.

Feature: Are there adjoined relative clauses?
Comment: There are not enough clausal examples available.

Feature: Is there a decimal numeral system?
Example: 30 elan dZan, 40 diGin dZan, 50 tonNa dZan, 60 nuNun dZan, 70 nadan dZan, 80 dZapkun dZan, 90 ijeGin dZan

Feature: Is there synchronic evidence for any element of a quinary numeral system?
Example: 1 omon, 2 dZu:l, 3 elan, 4 diGin, 5 tonNa, 6 nuNun, 7 nadan, 8 dZapkun, 9 ijeGin, 10 dZan

Feature: Is there synchronic evidence for any element of a vigesimal numeral system?
Example: 40 diGin dZan, 60 nuNun dZan, 80 dZapkun dZan

Feature: Is there a body-part tallying system?
Are all person categories neutralized in some voice, tense, aspect, mood and/or negation?
Is there a class of patient-labile verbs?
Does the verb for 'see' have suppletive verb forms?
Detailed comment: There is no suppletion whatsoever.

Feature: Does the verb for 'come' have suppletive verb forms?
Detailed comment: There is no suppletion whatsoever.

Feature: Is there any accusative alignment of flagging?
Is there any ergative alignment of flagging?
Is there any neutral alignment of flagging?
Comment: “Nominative case in Negidal is never used for marking direct object unlike Nanai and some other Tungus-Manchu languages.”

Feature: Is there a politeness distinction in 2nd person forms?
Is there a preposed complementizer in complements of verbs of thinking and/or knowing?
Comment: There are not enough clausal examples available.

Feature: Is there a postposed complementizer in complements of verbs of thinking and/or knowing?
Comment: There are not enough clausal examples available.

Feature: Can adnominal possession be marked by a prefix on the possessor?
Can adnominal possession be marked by a prefix on the possessed noun?
Can adnominal possession be marked by a suffix on the possessor?
Can adnominal possession be marked by a suffix on the possessed noun?
Example:
inalienable: deli-nin [head-3SG] ‘his head’ (part of his body)
alienable: deli-Ni-nin [head-POSS-3SG] ‘his head’ (of the animal, slaughtered by him)
absolutive: taj del mojin-Ni [that head horse-POSS] ‘that head is the horse’s one’

Feature: Can mood be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Can aspect be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Can tense be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Can the S or A argument be omitted from a pragmatically unmarked clause when the referent is inferrable from context ("pro-drop" or "null anaphora")?
Is root structure predominantly polysyllabic?
Are complex tonal distinctions lacking?
Detailed comment: There is vowel length distinction. In non-initial syllables vowel length is conceived as ‘stress’.

Feature: Is there palatal vowel harmony?
Detailed comment: Tsintsius (1997:191): height opposition, in Tsintsius (1982): nothing mentioned about vowel harmony.

Feature: Is there tongue root vowel harmony?
Detailed comment:
Tsintsius (1997:191): height opposition, in Tsintsius (19982) there is nothing mentioned about vowel harmony.
Oskolskaya: “The use of vowels is governed by the rules of a vowel harmony. Vowels are divided into three groups on the basis of height: high vowels ɵ, ɵ:, ə, low vowels (e), e:, (ʊ), (ʊ:), o, o:, a. a: and neutral vowels i, i:, u, u:. A word can contain only high (bɵjə-wɵ man-ACC) or only low vowels (ǯo:-wa house-ACC). Neutral vowels can occur in words of both phonological types”

Feature: Is there an initial velar nasal?
Example: NaNta ‘fir-tree’

Feature: Is there an initial r-?
Detailed comment: All consonants can be found in initial position, apart from r, which is a non-frequent consonant in Negidal. It appears most often in borrowings.

Feature: Are there initial consonant clusters in native words?
Is there a voicing distinction in stops?
Are borrowed verbs accommodated through a light-verb or a verbalizer?
Detailed comment: Not mentioned.

Feature: Are property words verbally or nominally encoded?
Is there partial emphatic reduplication of nominal property words?
Detailed comment: There is partial and full reduplication of ideophones (functioning as property adverbs). There is no reduplication mentioned for adjetives.
Example: bagda-bagda ‘very white’, xola-xola ‘very red’, tak-tax ‘to keep tight’

Feature: Are morphemes connected linearly in a way that there is a one on one relationship between a morpheme and its meaning?
Is inflectional morphology predominantly suffixing?
Detailed comment: exclusively suffing

Feature: Is there a mi-ti opposition in 1 vs. 2 SG personal pronouns?
Detailed comment: mi-si opposition

Feature: Is the secondary oblique stem of personal pronouns formed with a dental nasal?
Example:
bi
[1SG.NOM]
min
[1SG.OBL]

Feature: Are gerunds or adverbial participles used to mark adverbial subordination?
Example:
gu:nmi: ətəji-la:-j budZes ‘you will die after you stop talking’
ta:du: ojon bisi:-la:-n Nənəda:vəj ‘then go to the place where the deer is’
ju:ča:-dZi-vəj ‘having gone out, (they) …’
sali-ča:-du:-n salijen ‘he is having lunch where the other one was having lunch’ (at the other one’s place of having lunch)

Feature: Are specific non-finite and finite suffixes expressed by a formally identical suffix?
Are specific negative verbs and negative suffixes/particles expressed by a formally identical suffix?
Can 1PL marker be augmented by a collective plural marker?
Detailed comment: Plural personal pronouns can acquire number marker in the meaning of a complete set of participants ‘we/you all’, e.g. sun-al-ba you-pl-acc.def ‘you all’.

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like nouns in predicative position?
Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as nouns?
Example:
bajan bəje-l
[rich person-PL]
‘rich people’

Feature: Is there a non-initial velar nasal?
Is there a reciprocal marker that is distinct from the reflexive marker?
Are there deranked purpose clauses?
Can the notional subject of a want complement clause be left implicit when it is coreferential with the wanter?
Is there a voicing distinction in fricatives?
Are there two separate liquid phonemes (r/l)?
Detailed comment: “A trill r occurs very occasionally in Negidal, mostly in recent loanwords or ideophones. According to (Pevnov, Khasanova 2006), it is sometimes used before k as a variant of l: əlkəǯin ~ ərkəǯin ‘slowly’ […]. ”

Feature: Is there vowel length distinction?
Are causative posture verbs derived and static-dynamic verbs basic?
Is there a male/female distinction in the sibling terms from the perspective of the speaker?
Is there an age distinction in sibling terms?
Are nouns most commonly derived from verbs than the other way around?
Are ‘hand’ and ‘arm’ expressed by the same term?
Are ‘moon’ and ‘month’ expressed by the same term?
Is there a plural/collective suffix that is restricted to animates?
Detailed comment: “The suffix ‑sal~‑səl is used more rarely and mainly with nouns denoting persons”, but Tsintsius (1982:20) gives examples with this suffix used on inanimate nouns.
Example:
ʤo:-sal [house-PL]
adeli-l, adeli-sal [net-PL]
moji-l, moji-sal [horse-PL]
sama:-sal ‘shamans’

Feature: Can scalar additive operators (‘even’) also be used in non-scalar contexts (also)?
Is there a reflexive-possessive affix?
Detailed comment: -ji

Feature: Are demonstratives verbally encoded?
Do cardinal numerals require agreement on noun phrases?
Example:
ʤu:-təl bọjə-vọ
[two-DISTR person-ACC]
‘two people’

Feature: Is nominative case unmarked?
Are accusative-marked objects specific while unmarked objects are non-specific?
Detailed comment:
“Nominative case in Negidal is never used for marking direct object unlike Nanai and some other Tungus-Manchu languages.”
There are different markers for definite and indefinite objects.

Feature: Are recipient and location expressed by the same marker?
Detailed comment: In some positions locative cases (locative, prolocative, ablative) include a dative case marker -du before their proper form, but they do not consist of the dative marker only.

Feature: Is there a distinction between marking of interrogation in polar and content questions?
Detailed comment: there are no suffixes to mark content interrogation

Feature: Is acting agent in passive clause expressed by a dative-marked noun phrase?
Example:
ujguli-du wa:-w-ča:-n
[huge.bear-DAT kill-PASS-PST-3SG]
‘(He) was killed by a huge bear.’

Feature: Is the subject of an adnominalized clause marked by the genitive case?
Can a passive construction have adversative meaning?
Can demonstrative/interrogative verbs be derived from pronouns and light verbs ‘to do’?
Are causative and passive expressed by a formally identical marker?
Detailed comment:
CAUS: -vka:n, -mka:n, -vka:t-/č-, -mka:t-/č-
PASS: -v-

Feature: Are converb suffixes and deverbal noun suffixes formally identical?
Are quotative markers adverbial derivations from a verb ‘to say’?
Can relational adpositions (e.g. ‘under’) be derived from a place noun (e.g. ‘bottom’) and a locational suffix (e.g. at LOC)?
Detailed comment: “‑gida (‑jida, ‑ŋida, ‑lida) denotes a place near the object, it usually derives postpositions’”
Example:
boga-jda-
[place-LOC]
’near (lit. near place)’

Feature: Are hortatives/purposives encoded by the same marker (eventually involving a converb of the verb ‘to say’)?
Are denominal verbalizers and deverbal suffixes sharing comparable actional semantics expressed by the same marker?
Is ‘it is becoming if’ grammaticalized in deontic modality?
Is imperative form for 2SG identical to bare verb root?
Detailed comment: -xal
Example:
si əgdiŋə mu:lək-kə ǯawa-xal
[2SG big bucket-ACC.DEF take-IMP.2SG]
‘take a big bucket’

Feature: Is person marking on the verb formally identical to independent personal pronouns?
Is there a comparative construction that employs a marker of the standard which elsewhere has a meaning ‘to see’?
Can a copula be derived from original posture verbs?
Can the notional subject of a want complement clause be expressed overtly when it is coreferential with the wanter?
Are ‘foot’ and ‘leg’ expressed by the same term?
Are there balanced purpose clauses?
Is there an adposition or a particle formally similar to the verb?
Is completive aspect expressed by a marker formally identical to the verb ’to put/throw away’?
Are there adpositions to mark core NPs?
Are there adpositions to mark oblique NPs?
Are there three laryngeal contrasts for stops?
Can numeral precede the noun?
Example:
ʤu:-təl bọjə-vọ
[two-DISTR person-ACC]
‘two people’

Feature: Can numeral follow the noun?
Can demonstrative precede the noun?
Can demonstrative follow the noun?
Can adnominal possessor precede the possessed noun?
Can adnominal possessor follow the possessed noun?
Can adnominal property word precede the noun?
Example:
bajan bəje-l
[rich person-PL]
‘rich people’

Feature: Can adnominal property word follow the noun?
Can adnominal collective universal quantifier (‘all’) precede the noun?
Can adnominal collective universal quantifier (‘all’) follow the noun?
Is there height vowel harmony?
Is there labial vowel harmony?
Is there an initial l-?
Do numerals have the same form in attributive and predicative use?
Is the meaning ‘to hunt’ expressed as noun+denominalizer?
Are instrumental and comitative expressed by the same marker?
Are the meanings ‘to see’ and ‘to try’ expressed by formally identical verbs?
What is the order of personal possessive suffixes and case suffixes?
Possible Values: 0: one category missing; 1: POSS-case; 2: case-POSS; 3: both

Feature: Is the pragmatically unmarked order of SV in intransitive clauses?
Is the pragmatically unmarked order of VS in intransitive clauses?
Is there an aspiration distinction in stops?
